facts.text: Petitioner was arrested on November 8, 1971 pursuant to the order of detention of the same date passed under sub-s. (1) a iii read with sub-s. 2 of S. 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 26 of 1971.
Grounds of detention were served on petitioner and matter reported to State Government on November 8, 1971.
On November 16, 1971 the State Government accorded its approval and made necessary report to Central Government.
Case placed before Advisory Board on December 3, 1971.
Petitioner's representation received by State Government on December 6, 1971.
Petitioner's representation considered by State Government on January 8, 1972, nearly 33 days after receipt.
Advisory Board gave its decision on January 13, 1972.
Order of detention affirmed by State Government on January 22, 1972.
Detenu communicated of affirmation order on January 25, 1972.
There was war with Pakistan from December 3, 1971 to December 17, 1971.
Respondent's explanation for delay: go-slow movement by State Government employees caused dislocation; increase in volume of work relating to detentions under the Act; movement of files delayed.
Delay unintentional and beyond control of State Government.
Detenu-petitioner stated he had not appealed to Calcutta High Court; respondent averred he applied for habeas corpus (Crl. Misc. No. 958 of 1972) pending there.
Detenu-petitioner is a notorious thief of copper wires and cables; his activities disrupted telegraphic communication system of railways and caused dislocation of railway service.

legal_issues.text: Whether the State Government considered the petitioner's representation after undue delay of 33 days, rendering the detention illegal.

petitioner_arguments.text: State Government considered his representation after undue delay and detention must be considered illegal on this ground.

respondent_arguments.text: Delay due to go-slow movement by employees, increase in detention work, file movement delays; unintentional and beyond control; may be condoned.
Petitioner applied to Calcutta High Court for habeas corpus which is pending.
Detenu is notorious thief disrupting railways.

court_reasoning.text: Too leisurely manner of dealing with safeguards against arbitrary preventive detention is wholly inconsistent with constitutional importance of personal freedom; representation must be considered expeditiously without avoidable delay, implicit in Art. 22(5).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Preventive detention requires prompt compliance with constitutional and statutory safeguards.

court_reasoning.text: No rigid time limit, but prima facie unreasonable delay must be satisfactorily explained; explanation here extremely vague, no real obstacle to considering within reasonable time.
War not relied on by respondent; effect left open; no opinion expressed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decision not based on war circumstances.

court_reasoning.text: High Court petition details unclear; no basis to await its decision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dispose of Art. 32 petition on merits.

court_reasoning.text: Detenu's activities do not absolve authorities of constitutional obligations; safeguards must be complied with in all situations.

holdings.text: Violation of Art. 22 or mandatory provisions of detention law renders detention invalid even if valid ab initio.
Delay in considering representation unexplained and unreasonable, detention illegal.

statutes_cited.name: Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971
statutes_cited.relevance: Detention order passed under these provisions

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition under Art. 32 for enforcement of fundamental rights; safeguards implicit in Art. 22(5); minimum procedure for preventive detention

outcome.summary: Writ petition allowed; detenu-petitioner directed to be set at liberty forthwith due to unexplained delay in considering representation.

key_quotes.text: too leisurely a manner of dealing with the statutory provisions relating to safeguards against arbitrary or illegal orders of preventive detention... is wholly inconsistent with the fundamental importance attached by our Constitution to the question of personal freedom
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes urgency required for detention safeguards

key_quotes.text: The representation made by the detenu to the State has, therefore, to be considered as early as possible, or in other words as expeditiously as practicable without avoidable delay.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States the legal standard for considering representations

key_quotes.text: The explanation for the delay in the present case is so extremely vague that we find it almost impossible to hold that... there was any real, genuine obstacle
key_quotes.speaker: court
